objection_handlers.objection: We already have repo vendors we've worked with for years
objection_handlers.underlying_concern: Change is risky and current relationships feel safe even if underperforming
objection_handlers.authentic_response: I understand loyalty to long-term partners. What I'm hearing from collections executives is they kept those relationships until they faced a compliance issue or their CFO demanded better numbers. The question isn't whether to keep vendors you trust - it's whether those vendors are equipped for today's regulatory environment and performance expectations. Would you be open to a side-by-side comparison on a small test batch to see if there's actually a meaningful difference in results?
objection_handlers.validation: Acknowledges relationship value while focusing on measurable outcomes rather than attacking current vendors

objection_handlers.objection: Your pricing is higher than what we're paying now
objection_handlers.underlying_concern: Budget constraints and fear of justifying increased costs to finance
objection_handlers.authentic_response: You're right that our per-unit fee is [AMOUNT] higher. Let me show you why that matters less than you think: if we recover vehicles [NUMBER] days faster, the improved liquidation value averages [DOLLAR AMOUNT] higher per unit. On a portfolio of [NUMBER] repos annually, that's [DOLLAR AMOUNT] in improved net recovery - which more than offsets the fee difference. Plus, what's the cost of one compliance violation or lawsuit from improper repo practices? Most of our clients found they were being 'penny wise and pound foolish' focusing only on the assignment fee.
objection_handlers.validation: Addresses price directly with specific ROI math rather than deflecting, and introduces risk cost that's often ignored

objection_handlers.objection: We need to run this through procurement and that takes months
objection_handlers.underlying_concern: Bureaucratic process feels overwhelming and becomes excuse for inaction
objection_handlers.authentic_response: I completely understand procurement requirements - most of our financial services clients have similar processes. Here's what we've learned works: while procurement does their full evaluation, we can run a pilot program under your existing vendor management framework. You assign us [NUMBER] accounts in [REGION], we prove the performance difference with actual data, and that gives you the business case to accelerate procurement approval. Would starting with a contained pilot while running parallel procurement make sense?
objection_handlers.validation: Respects their process while offering practical path forward that reduces risk and builds internal proof

objection_handlers.objection: We're concerned about coverage in rural areas and secondary markets
objection_handlers.underlying_concern: Previous vendors overpromised national coverage but couldn't actually serve difficult locations
objection_handlers.authentic_response: That's a legitimate concern because you've probably been told 'we cover everywhere' and then found out that meant 'everywhere we feel like going.' Let's do this differently: give me your three hardest-to-serve ZIP codes right now. I'll show you exactly which agents we'd assign them to, their actual location success rates in those areas, and typical recovery timeframes. If we can't demonstrate real coverage with real performance data, you shouldn't use us for those markets. Fair enough?
objection_handlers.validation: Acknowledges the real problem of overpromised coverage and offers concrete proof rather than generic assurances

objection_handlers.objection: Our IT team is overwhelmed and can't handle another integration
objection_handlers.underlying_concern: Past vendor implementations were painful and IT has integration fatigue
objection_handlers.authentic_response: I hear this a lot, and honestly, IT resistance has killed deals even when collections wanted to move forward. Our implementation is designed specifically for that reality. We integrate with [LOS/SERVICING SYSTEMS] using standard formats your IT team already supports - typically 2-4 hours of their time total. We handle the heavy lifting, provide test environments, and don't go live until your IT signs off. Can I have a 20-minute technical call with your IT lead to walk through exactly what we'd need from them? Let them tell you if it's actually burdensome.
objection_handlers.validation: Validates IT concerns as legitimate, provides specific implementation scope, and offers to let IT evaluate directly

objection_handlers.objection: We need to see references from lenders our size in our markets
objection_handlers.underlying_concern: Fear that service quality for smaller clients won't match what large institutions receive
objection_handlers.authentic_response: Absolutely reasonable - you want to talk to someone facing similar challenges, not just hear our largest client success stories. I can connect you with [CLIENT TYPE] in [REGION] with a portfolio size of [RANGE] - similar to yours. They can tell you honestly about our performance, how we handled problems when they came up, and whether we deliver the same service to mid-size clients as we do to the nationals. I'd rather you hear the unvarnished truth from them than just take my word for it. Would a reference call this week work?
objection_handlers.validation: Enthusiastically agrees rather than being defensive, offers truly comparable references, and acknowledges service consistency concerns

objection_handlers.objection: What happens if you can't perform and we need to switch back?
objection_handlers.underlying_concern: Fear of being trapped with an underperforming vendor and having no exit strategy
objection_handlers.authentic_response: That's exactly the right question to ask, and here's our answer: we don't lock you into long-term contracts because we don't want clients who feel trapped. You can terminate with [TIMEFRAME] notice. More importantly, if we're not hitting the performance metrics we committed to in the first [TIMEFRAME], you can exit immediately without penalty. We'd rather lose a client quickly than damage your portfolio by underperforming. Does having that exit flexibility address your concern?
objection_handlers.validation: Treats exit strategy as smart business rather than lack of confidence, provides specific terms that reduce switching risk

Repo 101: What lenders need to know about breach of peace violations (thread)

1/ Breach of peace during repossession = major legal liability. Yet many lenders don't know what actually constitutes a violation. Let's break it down:

2/ BREACH OF PEACE INCLUDES:
 Entering locked garages without permission
 Using force or threats
 Breaking locks or gates
 Repossessing despite debtor's verbal objection
 Causing physical confrontation

3/ WHAT MOST PEOPLE DON'T KNOW:
Verbal objection alone can constitute breach of peace. If debtor says "don't take it," professional agents must cease and pursue legal remedies instead.

4/ THE COST:
 Lawsuits ranging $[AMOUNT_LOW]-$[AMOUNT_HIGH]
 Punitive damages possible
 Regulatory penalties
 Reputational damage
 Contract termination

5/ PROTECTION STRATEGIES:
 Hire only licensed, bonded agencies
 Require body camera documentation
 Implement clear escalation protocols
 Regular compliance audits
 Written policies for objection scenarios

6/ At [COMPANY_NAME], we've maintained zero breach incidents over [TIMEFRAME] through systematic training and clear protocols. Compliance isn't optionalit's foundational.

educational.hook: Think repo agents just tow cars? Here's what REALLY happens in 60 seconds.
educational.body: When a lender contracts us, we don't just show up randomly. First, we verify the legal right to repossess through court orders or contract default proof. Then we use skip tracing to locate the assetoften taking weeks. The actual recovery? That's maybe 5% of our work. We document everything with timestamps, photos, and condition reports to protect all parties. We inventory personal property, store it securely, and follow state-specific redemption laws. Most people don't know: you have rights during repo, including redemption periods and personal property retrieval. We're not the bad guyswe're licensed professionals following legal process.
